etymology.description: semantic 米(米) (mǐ, "rice") + phonetic 唐(唐) (táng, "Tang dynasty") = rice-based sweetener -> sugar
etymology.interpretation: The character 糖(táng) combines 米(米) (mǐ, "rice"), indicating that sugar can be derived from grain-based sources like rice, with 唐(唐) (táng), which provides the sound. This reflects the historical use of grain in sweeteners.

examples.chinese: 妈妈在烘焙时用糖调味(媽媽在烘焙時用糖調味)。
examples.pinyin: Māmā zài hōngbèi shí yòng táng tiáowèi.
examples.english: Mom uses sugar to flavor the baked goods.

examples.chinese: 他煮咖啡时放了糖(他煮咖啡時放了糖)，使味道更加浓郁(使味道更加濃郁)。
examples.pinyin: Tā zhǔ kāfēi shí fàng le táng, shǐ wèidào gèngjiā nóngyù.
examples.english: He added sugar when brewing the coffee, which made the flavor richer.

examples.chinese: 秋天的时候有人卖糖(秋天的時候有人賣糖)，这种糖在节日里很受欢迎(這種糖在節日裡很受歡迎)。
examples.pinyin: Qiūtiān de shíhòu yǒurén mài táng, zhèzhǒng táng zài jiérì lǐ hěn shòu huānyíng.
examples.english: In autumn, someone sells sugar, and this kind of sugar is very popular during festivals.
